title: 86-B
statement: B. Tetris revisitedtime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutPhysicist Woll likes to play one relaxing game in between his search of the theory of everything.Game interface consists of a rectangularn×mplaying field and a dashboard. Initially some cells of the playing field are filled while others are empty. Dashboard contains images of all various connected (we mean connectivity by side) figures of 2, 3, 4 and 5 cells, with all their rotations and reflections. Player can copy any figure from the dashboard and place it anywhere at the still empty cells of the playing field. Of course any figure can be used as many times as needed.Woll's aim is to fill the whole field in such a way that there are no empty cells left, and also... just have some fun.Every initially empty cell should be filled with exactly one cell of some figure. Every figure should be entirely inside the board.In the picture black cells stand for initially filled cells of the field, and one-colour regions represent the figures.InputFirst line contains integersnandm(1 ≤n,m≤ 1000) — the height and the width of the field correspondingly. Nextnlines containmsymbols each. They represent the field in a natural way:j-th character of thei-th line is "#" if the corresponding cell is filled, and "." if it is empty.OutputIf there is no chance to win the game output the only number "-1" (without the quotes). Otherwise output any filling of the field by the figures in the following format: each figure should be represented by some digit and figures that touch each other by side should be represented by distinct digits. Every initially filled cell should be represented by "#".ExamplesInput2 3...#.#Output000#0#Input3 3.#......#Output5#151155#Input3 3....##.#.Output-1Input1 2##Output##NoteIn the third sample, there is no way to fill a cell with no empty neighbours.In the forth sample, Woll does not have to fill anything, so we should output the field from the input.

processed.result:
You are given a rectangular playing field of size $n \times m$. Some cells are initially filled ("#") and others are empty (".")

You have a set of Tetris-like figures of sizes 2, 3, 4, and 5 cells. You can place these figures anywhere on the empty cells of the field, rotating and reflecting them as needed.

The goal is to fill the entire field with the figures so that:

* Every cell is filled by exactly one figure.
* Every figure is entirely within the field boundaries.

If it's impossible to fill the entire field, output "-1". Otherwise, output a valid filling of the field where:

* Each figure is represented by a unique digit.
* Figures touching by side are represented by different digits.
* Initially filled cells are represented by "#".

You are given a rectangular grid partially filled with blocks. You have a set of different shaped blocks of sizes 2x2, 3x3, 4x4, and 5x5.  You can place these blocks onto empty spaces in the grid, but they must fit completely within the grid boundaries and not overlap.  

Determine if it is possible to fill the entire grid with these blocks. If it is possible, show one way to do it.
